abstract.label: Abstract
abstract.p: Formal Christian theological training/education is unsurprisingly diverse. This diversity in theological training encompasses: providers and beneficieries from different denominations of modern Christianity, curricula and contents, and aims. If one supposes that theological training is imparted within or in direct/indirect relations with communities of faith (which likely possess different notions of theology and theological training/education) one is compelled to ask: What is ‘theological education’? Is this quest worth the effort?

fn.p: This question, it must be noted, implies a prior question: ‘What kind(s) of person should be a theologically educated person(s)?’ I am assuming that the answer to this question is that all kinds of persons should as a base threshold be theologically educated to the degree that is fit for the purpose of their being as fully as possible mature in their faith.

David Jenkins persistently recommended that in reading the Bible the reader has always to ask ‘How did people think then which led them to put it like that?’ He provided the following as an example. The writers of the gospels lived at a time when demon possession was the available conceptuality if a person fell to the ground writhing and foaming at the mouth. In the Middle Ages, the conceptuality within which explanation arose was that of the humours of the body and the cure would have been blood-letting. In medicalized 21st century conceptuality, it would be said that the person was having an epileptic fit and the needed response is to keep calm and re-assure.

There is a case, however, for seeing research as necessarily being involved in its first stage in ‘strangemaking’. It is only by making the commonplace first of all ‘strange’ that one can attain the critical distance required for research to proceed. Ethnomethodology makes this its primary mode of practice. Garfinkel, its originator, analysed in detail the methods used by people in everyday life to account for (make sense of) their activities for themselves and for others. He thus saw ethnomethodology as the study of commonsense knowledge of social structures so as to make sociological reasoning analysable. Ethnomethodology was the subject of fierce debate within sociology departments. Some of its insights have been taken into mainstream sociological theory, particularly through the work of Anthony Giddens.

See the classic study,Barnes DR, Britton JN and Torbe M (1989) Language, the Learner, and the School. Portsmouth, NH: Boynton/Cook. It argues that stress on ‘proper English’ can inhibit non-middle-class children from expressing themselves in the kind of language they use at home, while ‘learning’ for all too many students means guessing what answers the teacher expects – in ‘school language’ of course. The final section makes important recommendations on the major issue of language across the curriculum – what sort of language is really appropriate in multicultural schools? A charismatic evangelical teacher-training student I supervised some years ago was convinced that modern teenagers can understand Christian doctrine if only the teacher can find the right teaching methods including exciting visual aids. He admitted failure having tried.

Philadelphia, PA & Boston, MA: Pilgrim Press, http://www.religion-online.org/showbook.asp?title=2300 (accessed 18 February 2010). Chapter 5, ‘Discernment and Commitment’ is based on IT Ramsey who argued that religious language is grounded in personal experience and personal disclosure. This understanding of religious language is experientially grounded in that when we communicate with each other personal disclosure occurs. Ramsey argued that we come to encounter God it is also by way of personal disclosure. Ramsey’s theological work thus continues the traditional theological view that all religious language is analogical, and the religious vocabulary that we create always involves the language of analogy.

This is partly an allusion to Wittgenstein on language games but I am emphasising the sense of play to add to what he says of games, life and travel. On language games, see more inStanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy, http://plato.stanford.edu/entries/feminist-religion/ (accessed 18 February 2010): Some properties of language-games can be noticed in Wittgenstein’s several examples and comments. They are, first, a part of a broader context termed by Wittgenstein a form of life (see below). Secondly, the concept of language-games points at the rule-governed character of language. This does not entail strict and definite systems of rules for each and every language-game, but points to the conventional nature of this sort of human activity. Finally, Wittgenstein’s choice of ‘game’ is based on the over-all analogy between language and game, assuming that we have a clearer perception of what games are. Still, just as we cannot give a final, essential definition of ‘game’, so we cannot find ‘what is common to all these activities and what makes them into language or parts of language.’

I am indebted for this distinction to colleagues at St Paul’s Limuru, Kenya, who offer an MA in Community Care and HIV/AIDS which delivers actual care and training of carers as an intrinsic part of the qualification. The terms were used by a visiting party from Cote d’Ivoire who were comparing their own theology curriculum with that of the SPL MA which is premised on theology being expressive response to the world as it is held before God. OCMS led the design of this MA.

‘The action turn’ stands over against ‘the linguistic turn’ that was a development in Western philosophy during the 20th century. Its most important characteristic is its focus on philosophy and language. Ludwig Wittgenstein’s influence is strong as the term follows from his claim that philosophical problems arise from a misunderstanding of the logic of language and his later comments on language games. SeeReason P & Torbert WR (2001) The Action Turn: Toward a Transformational Social Science: a further look at the scientific merits of action research.
